content: Rahm <span class="word-wrap-span">Emanuelspan>, the mayor, is <span class="word-wrap-span">assailspan>ed from all sides ![Playing politics after a weekend of carnage in Chicago ](https://cdn.static-economist.com/sites/default/files/20180811_USP503.jpg) AS THE <span class="word-wrap-span">balmyspan> Sunday evening of August 5th wound down, the Chicago Police Department (<span class="word-wrap-span">CPDspan>) was out in force on North Avenue Beach. Officers guarded the trendy Shore Club and watched <span class="word-wrap-span">Castawayspan>s, a beach bar shaped like a boat. The watering holes are often trouble spots during very hot weekends. It had already been a particularly <span class="word-wrap-span">brutalspan> one, with the violence peaking early on Sunday, when 30 people were shot in a three-hour span between midnight and 3am. By the end of the weekend 12 people had been had been shot dead, two children among them. Almost 60 were injured in shootings, of which two dozen were children. “We have a heavy heart,” said Rahm <span class="word-wrap-span">Emanuelspan>, the mayor of Chicago, at a press conference on August 6th. “What happened this weekend did not happen in every neighbourhood in Chicago, but it is unacceptable to happen in any neighborhood in Chicago,” he said. The <span class="word-wrap-span">epidemicspan> of shootings and killings tends to be <span class="word-wrap-span">confinespan>d to four or five neighbourhoods on the South and West sides of the city. The <span class="word-wrap-span">bloodshedspan> comes as Chicago’s <span class="word-wrap-span">epidemicspan> of violent crime seemed to be abating at last, especially in some of the most <span class="word-wrap-span">murderousspan> parts of the city. After 2016 turned out to be the <span class="word-wrap-span">deadliestspan> year for two decades, with 762 murders and 3,550 shootings, the following year was less bloody, with 650 murders and 2,785 shootings. So far this year 318 people have been killed, 110 fewer than at this point last year. In some neighbourhoods the change for the better was <span class="word-wrap-span">remarkablespan>. Englewood, a hard-up, <span class="word-wrap-span">predominantlyspan> black neighbourhood on the South Side, saw a decline in murders of 44% and a drop in shootings of 43% in 2017 compared with the previous year. This <span class="word-wrap-span">carnagespan> of the past weekend is a <span class="word-wrap-span">setbackspan> for Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">Emanuelspan>, who is running for re-election in February. Crime is one of the reasons for his declining popularity among the city’s back voters, who <span class="word-wrap-span">representspan> around one-third of Chicago’s <span class="word-wrap-span">electoratespan>. On August 2nd mostly black activists organised an anti-violence march on the North Side. They demanded the <span class="word-wrap-span">resignationspan> of Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">Emanuelspan> and <span class="word-wrap-span">Eddiespan> Johnson, his police chief. In early July Father Michael Pfleger, the activist <span class="word-wrap-span">Catholicspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">priestspan> of St <span class="word-wrap-span">Sabinaspan>, a <span class="word-wrap-span">parishspan> on the South Side, had led another anti-violence protest, which shut down one of the city’s major highways. Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">Emanuelspan>’s rivals for the mayor’s job wasted no time in attacking him for what they say is his failure to contain the violence. Paul Vallas, the former boss of Chicago Public Schools, <span class="word-wrap-span">lambastespan>d the mayor for failing to keep the police staffed with enough detectives to solve murders and shootings. The <span class="word-wrap-span">CPDspan>’s <span class="word-wrap-span">clearancespan> rate of violent crime is one of the worst of big American cities; around four of five murders remain unresolved. As of the evening of August 6th the <span class="word-wrap-span">CPDspan> had made no arrests connected to the weekend’s shootings. The former p<span class="word-wrap-span">residentspan> of the police board, <span class="word-wrap-span">Lorispan> Lightfoot, <span class="word-wrap-span">chimespan>d in to declare that public safety is “the right of every <span class="word-wrap-span">Chicagoanspan>—not a question of zip code or a commodity for the wealthy.” <span class="word-wrap-span">Garryspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">McCarthyspan>, a former boss of the <span class="word-wrap-span">CPDspan>, whom Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">Emanuelspan> sacked, <span class="word-wrap-span">mockspan>ed the mayor on Twitter and said a “state of <span class="word-wrap-span">emergencyspan>” should be declared in Chicago. What caused the sudden spike in violence? The hot weather played a role, but not all steamy days lead to violence. Much of it was linked to conflicts between gangs, according the <span class="word-wrap-span">CPDspan>. Gang members are using larger crowds as cover. “They shoot into a crowd, no matter who they hit,” said Fred <span class="word-wrap-span">Wallerspan>, chief of <span class="word-wrap-span">patrolspan> of the <span class="word-wrap-span">CPDspan>. The police also <span class="word-wrap-span">citespan>d the high number of guns in <span class="word-wrap-span">circulationspan>, the failure of courts and judges to <span class="word-wrap-span">convictspan> those caught with illegal guns and the need for parents to <span class="word-wrap-span">instillspan> the right values in their children. <span class="word-wrap-span">CPDspan> leaders <span class="word-wrap-span">implorespan>d <span class="word-wrap-span">residentspan>s of the most violent neighborhoods to get in touch to help the police solve crimes, but trust between the <span class="word-wrap-span">CPDspan> and poor blacks and <span class="word-wrap-span">Hispanicspan>s is <span class="word-wrap-span">scarcespan>.  <span class="word-wrap-span">Rudyspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">Giulianispan>, a former Republican mayor of New York and <span class="word-wrap-span">sidekickspan> of P<span class="word-wrap-span">residentspan> Donald Trump, blamed the problem on Chicago’s <span class="word-wrap-span">longtimespan> “<span class="word-wrap-span">Democratspan>ic rule” in a series of tweets. Reiterating his support for <span class="word-wrap-span">Garryspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">McCarthyspan> (whom he called "Jerry" and a "policing <span class="word-wrap-span">geniusspan>”) he claimed that the former <span class="word-wrap-span">CPDspan> boss can do a lot better than Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">Emanuelspan> (whose name he also misspelt) who he said was “fiddling while Chicago burns”. Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">Giulianispan> also falsely claimed that Chicago had “63 murders this weekend”. Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">McCarthyspan>, a <span class="word-wrap-span">Democratspan> who is also running for mayor, could have done without Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">Giulianispan>’s <span class="word-wrap-span">endorsementspan>  “I am a proud <span class="word-wrap-span">Democratspan> and I do not agree with Mayor <span class="word-wrap-span">Giulianispan>’s political views,” he said in a statement. Meanwhile Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">Emanuelspan> remained <span class="word-wrap-span">silentspan> about his <span class="word-wrap-span">opponentspan>s’ attempt to gain political capital from tragedy. He knows that violent crime, police reform, the poor state of some public schools and high property taxes will <span class="word-wrap-span">dominatespan> the <span class="word-wrap-span">mayoralspan> election. And although he is still the favourite to win, his career too could fall victim to the city’s <span class="word-wrap-span">endemicspan> violence.

ex: adj. 时髦的，流行的
n. 追求时髦者；新潮人物
eg2: The key is not to be buzzword compliant or to join the trendy game of buzzword bashing.
关键是不要盲目的追随这些时髦的词汇或者加入抨击这种流行词汇的游戏中。
But for all my trendy egalitarianism, there was one sacrifice that I would never have considered – giving up my job.
但是尽管我信奉目前时髦的男女平等的概念，有一样东西我是决不会放弃的---那就是我的工作。
But it is a bit likethose guys who wear their pants so low you can see ALL of theirunderwear or the people who take up smoking for the " image".
但是这有点像那些将裤子穿的很低以至别人都可以看到他们的内衣的家伙或者那些为了“时髦形象”而吸烟的人们。

wp.unacceptable character: 不可接受性;不能接受的字符;不可接受的字符

ex: adj. 不能接受的；不受欢迎的
eg2: There may be  changes at the project level.
在项目层次可能会有不能接受的变更。
The very idea would be foreign and unacceptable to main stream academics.
这种想法对主流学者而言是外来的和不能接受的。
To think we could not reach the finishing line because of lack of financial resources is .
想一想，如果我们因为缺少财力资源而不能达到终点，这是不能接受的。

ex: adj. 未解决的；无决断力的；不果断的

wp.Unresolved Cases: 未解决纠纷;未解决的投诉

eg2: But even with more than a century and a half of observations, many unresolved questions remain about the farthest planet from the sun.
不过，即使经过了一个半世纪的观测，这个距离太阳最远的行星，仍有许多尚未解决的问题。
I understand that you have feelings of unhappiness and  issues with your own family but, again, I ask you to examine why that means that you cannot find happiness with your own children?
我理解你的感觉，关于你自己的家庭的不快乐和未解决的问题，但是我再次请求你检查为什麽这意味著你不可以找到与你自己的孩子在一起的快乐？
Then there's the still unresolved issue of the very different experiences supplied by television and the Internet.
接下来，由于电视和网络提供的体验有所不同，因此仍然有尚未解决的问题。

ex: adj. 暴力的；猛烈的
eg2: The black cloud presignified a violent storm.
乌云预示着一场猛烈的暴风雨。
The speaker lashed the young people into violent action.
那个演讲者煽动青年人搞暴力行动。
The enemy troops began to reel in defeat under our violent attack.
敌军在我方的猛烈攻击下开始溃退。

ex: n. 拉链；拉锁；能量；速度
v. 拉上拉链；用拉链锁上；（使沿某方向）快速移动；压缩（文件）
网络 邮编；压缩档；解压缩
eg2: to do up/undo/open/close a zip
拉上╱拉开╱拉开╱拉上拉链
My zip's stuck.
我的拉链卡住了。
We won four zip(= 4–0) .
我们以四比零获胜。
He said zip all evening.
整个晚上他一声不吭。
I zipped and buttoned my jacket.
我把夹克的拉链拉上，系好扣子。
The children were safely zipped into their sleeping bags.
孩子们都安安稳稳地躺在睡袋里，拉链也给他们拉好了。
He zipped his case shut.
他拉上了箱子的拉锁。
The sleeping bags can zip together.
这些睡袋可用拉链连起来。
A sports car zipped past us.
一辆跑车从我们身边呼啸而过。

title: Playing politics after a weekend of carnage in Chicago

paperStatistics.title: Playing politics after a weekend of carnage in Chicago
paperStatistics.desc: Rahm Emanuel, the mayor, is assailed from all sides
